org.jtrim.image

Class ImageData

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jtrim.image.ImageData
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    MemoryHeavyObject

    public final class ImageData
extends java.lang.Object
implements MemoryHeavyObject
    Defines an image which was retrieved from an external source. Apart from the image itself, the ImageData contains the meta data information of the image and an exception associated with the image retrieval.

    Although it is possible to mutate the properties of an ImageData instance, the intended use of ImageData is to use it as an effectively immutable object. That is, its properties should not be modified (e.g.: The pixels of the BufferedImage should not be modified).

    This class implements the MemoryHeavyObject interface and approximates the size of an ImageData instance by the approximate size of the underlying BufferedImage.

    Note that this class also provides several useful static helper methods, to create BufferedImage instance better handled by the Java and methods to calculate the approximate size of a BufferedImage.

    Thread safety

    Methods of this class can be safely accessed by multiple threads. Although individual properties are not immutable, they should treated so. Users of this class can assume that the properties of ImageData are not modified and can be safely accessed by multiple concurrent threads as well.

    Synchronization transparency

    The methods of this class are synchronization transparent.

    • Constructor Detail

      • ImageData

        public ImageData(java.awt.image.BufferedImage image,
         ImageMetaData metaData,
         ImageReceiveException exception)
        Initializes the ImageData with the given image, meta data and exception describing the failure in retrieving the image.
        Parameters:
        image - the retrieved image. This argument can be null if no image could be retrieved (maybe because it is not (yet) available.
        metaData - the meta data information about the specified image. If both the meta data and the image is specified (i.e.: not null), the meta data must define the same dimensions for the image as the image itself. This argument can be null if no meta data information is available.
        exception - the error describing the failure of the image retrieval. Even in case of failure a partial or incomplete image might be available. This argument can be null if there was no failure in retrieving the image.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - thrown if both the image and the meta data is specified and they define different dimensions for the image.

    • Method Detail

      • getStoredPixelSize

        public static double getStoredPixelSize(java.awt.image.ColorModel cm)
        Returns the average size in bytes of a single pixel in the given ColorModel. The returned value might not be an integer because some ColorModel encodes pixels in a fraction of a byte (or just not in a multiple of eight bits).

        Note that for some obscure ColorModel this method may return an incorrect value but tries to return a good approximate in this cases as well.

        Parameters:
        cm - the ColorModel of which pixel size in bytes is to be returned. This argument cannot be null.
        Returns:
        the average size in bytes of a single pixel in the given ColorModel. This method always return a value greater than or equal to zero. A return value is zero is usually only theoretical since there is no such practical color model.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if the specified color model is null

      • getApproxSize

        public static long getApproxSize(java.awt.image.BufferedImage image)
        Returns the approximate memory in bytes the specified BufferedImage retains. The size is approximate by the size of all the pixels in the BufferedImage.
        Parameters:
        image - the BufferedImage whose size is to be approximated. This argument can be null, in which case zero is returned.
        Returns:
        the approximate memory in bytes the specified BufferedImage retains. This method always returns a value greater than or equal to zero.

      • getCompatibleBufferType

        public static int getCompatibleBufferType(java.awt.image.ColorModel colorModel)
        Returns the type of the BufferedImage which most closely approximates the specified ColorModel.

        The returned integer can be used as an image type for a BufferedImage. That is, this integer can be specified for the BufferedImage at construction time and will be returned by the BufferedImage.getType() method. Note however, that this method may return BufferedImage.TYPE_CUSTOM for which the constructor of BufferedImage will throw an exception but any other return value will be accepted by BufferedImage.

        Parameters:
        colorModel - the ColorModel which is to be approximated with a BufferedImage image type. This argument cannot be null.
        Returns:
        the BufferedImage image type which most closely approximates the specified ColorModel.

      • createCompatibleBuffer

        public static java.awt.image.BufferedImage createCompatibleBuffer(java.awt.image.BufferedImage image,
                                                  int width,
                                                  int height)
        Creates a returns a new BufferedImage which is compatible with the specified BufferedImage with the given dimensions. The returned BufferedImage will have the same ColorModel as the one specified. The returned BufferedImage is compatible in the sense that its pixels can be copied using simple array copies and does not require any other transformations.
        Parameters:
        image - the image to which a compatible BufferedImage is to be returned. This argument can be null, in which case null is returned.
        width - the width of the returned BufferedImage. This argument must be greater than zero.
        height - the height of the returned BufferedImage. This argument must be greater than zero.
        Returns:
        a new BufferedImage which is compatible with the specified BufferedImage with the given dimensions. This method returns null only if the specified image was also null.

      • cloneImage

        public static java.awt.image.BufferedImage cloneImage(java.awt.image.BufferedImage image)
        Returns a new BufferedImage which is the copy of the specified image. That is, returns an image which when modified does not affect the specified image. The returned and the specified BufferedImage have the same color model, dimensions and are otherwise compatible.
        Parameters:
        image - the image which is to be copied. This argument can be null, in which case null is returned.
        Returns:
        a new BufferedImage which is the copy of the specified image. This method returns null only if the specified image was also null.

      • createNewAcceleratedBuffer

        public static java.awt.image.BufferedImage createNewAcceleratedBuffer(java.awt.image.BufferedImage image)
        Returns a new image which have the same pixels as the specified image but is likely to be accelerated by the currently present graphics card (if there is any).

        This methods differs from createAcceleratedBuffer by always returning a new image which is independent from the argument. That is, modifications of the returned image have no effect on the image passed as an argument.

        Parameters:
        image - the base image to which an image is to be returned which is more likely to be accelerated by the currently present graphics card. If this method cannot do better, it will return a copy of this image. This argument can be null, in which case null is returned.
        Returns:
        the image having the same pixels as the specified image but is likely to be accelerated by the currently present graphics card. This method returns null only if the specified image was also null. Modifying the returned image has no effect on the image passed in the argument.
        See Also:
        createAcceleratedBuffer(BufferedImage), createNewOptimizedBuffer(BufferedImage)

      • createAcceleratedBuffer

        public static java.awt.image.BufferedImage createAcceleratedBuffer(java.awt.image.BufferedImage image)
        Returns an image which have the same pixels as the specified image but is likely to be accelerated by the currently present graphics card (if there is any).

        This method uses several undefined heuristics to determine the required image type and may also return an image which requires somewhat more memory to be stored.

        This method may return the same BufferedImage image as the one specified in the argument. If this is undesired, use the createNewAcceleratedBuffer method instead.

        Parameters:
        image - the base image to which an image is to be returned which is more likely to be accelerated by the currently present graphics card. This method may return this image if it cannot do better. This argument can be null, in which case null is returned.
        Returns:
        the image having the same pixels as the specified image but is likely to be accelerated by the currently present graphics card. This method returns null only if the specified image was also null.
        See Also:
        createNewAcceleratedBuffer(BufferedImage)

      • createNewOptimizedBuffer

        public static java.awt.image.BufferedImage createNewOptimizedBuffer(java.awt.image.BufferedImage image)
        Returns a new image which have the same pixels as the specified image but is likely to be more efficiently handled than the one specified.

        This methods differs from createOptimizedBuffer by always returning a new image which is independent from the argument. That is, modifications of the returned image have no effect on the image passed as an argument.

        Parameters:
        image - the base image to which an image is to be returned which is likely to be more efficiently handled in general. If this method cannot do better, it will return a copy of this image. This argument can be null, in which case null is returned.
        Returns:
        the image which have the same pixels as the specified image but is likely to be more efficiently handled than the one specified. This method returns null only if the specified image was also null.
        See Also:
        createNewAcceleratedBuffer(BufferedImage), createOptimizedBuffer(BufferedImage)

      • createOptimizedBuffer

        public static java.awt.image.BufferedImage createOptimizedBuffer(java.awt.image.BufferedImage image)
        Returns an image which have the same pixels as the specified image but is likely to be more efficiently handled than the one specified.

        Unlike createAcceleratedBuffer, this method does not consider graphic card acceleration. That is, this is a general purpose method and only employs heuristics for converting the image which are very likely to increase performance in general or at least does not downgrade performance. This method may also return an image which requires somewhat more memory to be stored.

        This method may return the same BufferedImage image as the one specified in the argument. If this is undesired, use the createNewOptimizedBuffer method instead.

        Parameters:
        image - the base image to which an image is to be returned which is likely to be more efficiently handled in general. This method may return this image if it cannot do better. This argument can be null, in which case null is returned.
        Returns:
        the image which have the same pixels as the specified image but is likely to be more efficiently handled than the one specified. This method returns null only if the specified image was also null.
        See Also:
        createAcceleratedBuffer(BufferedImage), createNewOptimizedBuffer(BufferedImage)

      • getException

        public ImageReceiveException getException()
        Returns the exception describing the failure of the image retrieval. This method returns the same exception as specified at construction time.

        Note that even in case of failure, a partial or incomplete image might still be available.

        Returns:
        the exception describing the failure of the image retrieval. This method may return null, if null was specified at construction time.

      • getImage

        public java.awt.image.BufferedImage getImage()
        Returns the retrieved image. The image might be incomplete or partial if not completely available or in case of some failure.
        Returns:
        the retrieved image. This method may return null, if null was specified at construction time.

      • getMetaData

        public ImageMetaData getMetaData()
        Returns the meta data information of the image. In case both the meta data and the image are specified, they define the same dimensions. That is, both getMetaData().getWidth() == getImage().getWidth() and getMetaData().getHeight() == getImage().getHeight() holds.
        Returns:
        the meta data information of the image. This method may return null, if null was specified at construction time.

      • getWidth

        public int getWidth()
        Returns the width of the image or -1 if it is unknown.

        If the meta data is available, the width is retrieved from the meta data, if not and the image is available, it is retrieved from the image.

        Returns:
        the width of the image or -1 if it is unknown

      • getHeight

        public int getHeight()
        Returns the height of the image or -1 if it is unknown.

        If the meta data is available, the height is retrieved from the meta data, if not and the image is available, it is retrieved from the image.

        Returns:
        the height of the image or -1 if it is unknown

      • getApproxMemorySize

        public long getApproxMemorySize()
        Returns the approximate size of memory in bytes, the image of this ImageData retains. That is, this method returns the same value as the ImageData.getApproxSize(getImage()) invocation.
        Specified by:
        getApproxMemorySize in interface MemoryHeavyObject
        Returns:
        the approximate size of memory in bytes, the image of this ImageData retains. This method always returns a value greater than or equal to zero.
